Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech, a fundamental democratic principle.
It creates a distinction between privileged groups (politicians, journalists, educators) and regular citizens, treating the latter as second-class.
Excessive fines will lead to a chilling effect on speech, making digital services more restrictive.
Determining truth is complex and evolving, as seen with COVID-19 information, and the bill could stifle open dialogue.
Delegating legislative power to private entities and ACMA raises constitutional concerns, infringing on political communication freedom.
The bill assumes government and accredited institutions can solely determine truth, suppressing diverse viewpoints.
Notable Quotes: This bill undermines the fundamental principle of freedom of speech that is vital to our democracy.
The internet, which is arguably the most powerful democratic invention, has given people a platform to express their thoughts and opinions.
The task of accurately determining what is true or untrue is an impossible one.
Restricting legitimate discussions on these matters curtails the constitutional freedom that underpins our democratic system.
